campaign.story:
This is me...And I want to share me with you and you with me.

As most things do, it started with a bang, disorientation and a slow unfurling of understanding.
"I walk to the backyard, smoke and contemplate the stars
Some vague sense of inconsequence
So small, but yet I am still here"
In 2017 I wrote a song called "Spit and Wire". When it was finished I knew it was different than the songs I had been writing. There are still only a handful of people that have heard it. At the time I wrote it I thought I couldn't share it because it was "too real". I was a worship pastor at the time and I thought "I shouldn't feel this way." "What would people think if they knew the struggles I have, if they knew the real me?" I didn't know it at the time but that song marked the beginning of a monumental shift in my life and I am so happy to be where I am now. I am happy to have come through the struggles I have faced, knowing that there are more ahead. Mostly, I am happy to share myself with the world and the songs that have come from this transformational experience in the last 3 years. 

2020...The year of the shift!
In the midst of writing songs, navigating my divorce and rebuilding my life I reached out to my brother in law, Miles Fuqua, about recording an album together. He is a super talented recording/mixing engineer and we had always talked about doing a project together and it was time to pull the trigger. After getting stoked about working together is when I discovered this project was going to call for more than a 10 song full length album. Once the ball started rolling I started connecting with other artists whose stories I resonated with. Thomas Bernardin, who produced the Kickstarter video is an inspirational storyteller/filmmaker who has a moving story of his own to tell. If the Kickstarter campaign is fulfilled, he is graciously offering to do an additional artistic video (video for a song, or mini-doc) on FILM! In the same spirit I reached out to Dustin Ransom, who is an astonishingly talented multi-instrumentalist here in Nashville, to play drums. Each of these collaborators will bring their own powerful layer of meaning, talent and energy into this project and I am so excited about the prospect of us all coming together to make this project a reality. 

The most important part is YOU!
All these dreams and plans are nice, but honestly, I can't do this without you. You are the collaborator that I am most importantly excited about working with. If there is any lesson that 2020 taught us, it's that we need one another. With your help I will be able to record these 3 EP's that are so important to me and close to my heart. Let's make something beautiful together!

The Plan
I have all the songs written for this project (and may even write a few more, who knows?) but at the least it will be 15 songs. Additionally, all the songs are demoed and the scratch tracks are ready and once the Kickstarter is fulfilled we will get to work! 
 May - Rehearsals with musicians
 May/June - Track drums, guitars, bass, keys, vocals, and all the extra goodness
 July - Mixing commences
 Mid August - Send song off for mastering, compile artwork, duplication
 October - Send out pre-release of all 3 EP's to Kickstarter backers
The Budget

Recording/Mixing/Mastering/Musicians/Duplication - $6,300 (Luckily I can keep this cost lower due to recording guitars/bass/keys/percussion myself)
Video/Art/Duplication - $2,700
Kickstarter Fees - $800-1,000
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
I think the biggest risk is not taking one. Hey, but let's get down to brass tax! Asking for help is pretty vulnerable for any artist so not reaching my goal would be a bummer wave, but I really believe we can do it. Some of the challenges will be time management and getting things done as outlined because there are always curve balls to deal with. Reward fulfillment is always a challenge but I tried to make most of the rewards digital in nature to mitigate some of those challenges. The stories and stems podcast will be a lot of work, but I am excited to do it. So, let's do this thang!

campaign.story:
Help me make my best album yet.
Early last year, I started writing a song called Poetry. It came in a blaze of creative glory, and I spent two days chasing down what I knew was something special. It's hard to describe the feeling, something like lightning, something like stumbling upon a vein of gold in the river and you wonder, how am I the one who gets to find it? When I wrote Poetry, I knew I wasn't just writing a song, but marking the next season of creating. I knew an album was being born. 
Since RIVER HOUSE released in 2017, I've spent the last 3 years discovering the real joy of my work: you. I've logged a lot of hours in your homes and living rooms on house concert tours, meeting you at weekend retreats in the woods, hearing your stories each night after a show. The world can be a hard and lonely place, and yet, we can find each other across the chasm of isolation, we can reach out a hand and be met by another. The songs for me are just a vehicle for the real joy of my life, which is being together. I like to think when I'm singing you my story, I'm also somehow mysteriously singing yours. I'm blown away every time you show up for me. I can never thank you enough.
I can't believe the caliber of folks coming alongside me to bring this record to life. At the helm is producer Lucas Morton (Jill Andrews, Jordy Searcy, Jon McLaughlin). We assembled a killer band, I mean, just wait till you hear these guys. The lineup: Will Sayles (Drew Holcomb & The Neighbors, Ben Rector, Carly Bannister) on drums, Tyler Burkum (Needtobreathe, The Cactus Blossoms, Ingrid Michaelson) on electric guitar,  Scott Mulvahill (Keb Mo, Joy Williams, Andrew Peterson), Justin Schipper (Kacey Musgraves, Tim McGraw, Shania Twain) on pedal steel, and Buckley Miller (Thad Cockrell, Mindy Mindy Smith, Katie Herzig) engineering, plus a heap of good friends lending their voices and talents. We are tracking all the songs on this album live, which essentially means we all get in a room together, push the record button, and see what happens :) It's how the best albums get made, in my opinion, and I knew I wanted this record to sound like the ones I've obsessed over: Emmylou Harris' Wrecking Ball, Alison Krauss & Robert Plant's Raising Sand, Brandi Carlile's By The Way I Forgive You.  You can expect an album that even in its moments of heady genius, is all feel, all personality, all heart.
The great news is, we've already gotten started! This February, before the world was thrown into a global pandemic, we packed in the B room at Oceanway Studios in Nashville and started tracking 4 of the 10 songs for the album. The original plan was to run a Kickstarter campaign in the spring and finish the album in 2020, but as we've all learned this year, some flexibility was required. To be honest, it's been a YEAR. I spent a good part of the last 6 months beat down and discouraged, not knowing when we'd pick the album back up, not knowing what was ahead for any of us. Through the encouragement of many of you, through some heart-to-hearts with my people, I remembered who I am and what I think I'm here on this earth to do. You reminded me  there IS a path forward, even if it's not the one we originally would have chosen. "The impeded stream is the one that sings" wrote Wendell Berry, and baby, we're singin.  
If you're reading this, thank you for caring about me and the music I make. Thank you for being with me all these years (or if you're new here, for taking a risk!) Wherever you are, I'd love you to come along for the ride on this one. I have a feeling it will be something special. Your Kickstarter pledge will go directly to music making, reserving studio space, paying for production, engineering, and the band, as well as printing, distribution, and marketing costs (see outlined budget below). To the right, there are lots of fun rewards exclusive to Kickstarters. Consider it my way of inviting you all the way into this project, cause DANG y'all, I couldn't do this without you.
all my love & gratitude,
Taylor

CDs, photography, videos, graphic design, advertising, promotion ..... $6,000

It's a big ask to run a kickstarter at a time when we're all trying to get through a difficult year. It might be a big ask to make an album at all. updates.update_content:
Hey Kickstarters -- my apologies for no update last night. Tuesday was our 2nd day of pre-pro and everything went well, spent the whole day making demos of all the songs to track to at Ocean Way.  When I got home, I ended up on a 2 hr face time with one of my oldest and dearest friends, and oh my heart needed it! 
Today was, well, beautiful!! I knew it would be meaningful and emotional to play with the band again, and I was right :) This crew...they are so special. We tracked two songs today: Grandfather Mountain and Mother's Daughter. I made a little video blog/update for you guys I'm posting below, along with some highlights from the day.

Dear world, dear people: I am utterly amazed and deeply grateful. Before I launched this Kickstarter, I was prepared for failure, knowing it was possible this would end in disappointment. I also knew there was a decent chance we could get there. I was WILDLY UNPREPARED, however, for this level of generosity and love from you all. I would not have believed you if you told me by the end we would raise $48,353 for the new album, 40% more than the original goal. And it’s more than money, I realize that. I know what you’ve really given me is your trust, your love, your belief in who I am and what I do and what we can make together. I am so honored you would see something good in me, something worth investing in, and I promise to take all that trust and love and belief and make something beautiful, something even better than I dreamed of on my own. I will find a thousand ways to tell you this: thank you. love, Taylor

Y'all are my heroes. I can't believe this but we've hit our initial goal of $27,000...so now we get to reach for a stretch goal!
Stretch goal: $31,000 for two additional songs on the record !!!!
I would love to be able to put more songs out into the world than we originally bargained for. But even if we don't raise one more dollar, I'm so incredibly blown away and grateful. Thank you, thank you, thank you!
This is it--the time has come to record a full length album! 
I even rollerbladed behind my car to tell you the news!
Am I scared? Maybe!!! Should I be telling you that? Probably not!!!
Here's the truth--my favorite thing about this job is you. Making music for a living is like making a career out of connecting. The songs I write that reflect my experience of loneliness, joy, questions, ~crushes~, are not complete until they are your songs too. Knowing that you are bringing your own story into these songs moves me to tears! real tears! What a deep breath that we both get to breathe, knowing we are not alone.
In light of, *gestures to 2020*, these last few months have been an all consuming experience of waking up to the grief of the world and to the urgent fight for change.  Learning how to live meaningful lives during a moment in history that is so brutally desperate for redemption is overwhelming to say the least. It's easy to fall into despair. My hope is that this record will help you fight that urge. That in a time of such chaos, you can find some comfort in these stories. I hope that these songs can walk along side you and cultivate some peace in your life while you continue to be that beautiful you. These songs are a direct result of my silliness, sadness, confusion, hope and sometimes my excruciating happiness. They are me :) And soon they will be all of ours!
Lucas Morton and Latifah Alattas are two of my dearest friends who will be co-producing the project. It's rare to find two people as thorough, hard working, and absolutely convinced of the magic in music. They are incredible musicians/producers/writers/creators/thinkers/innovators/you get it. Learning that I was going to work alongside them felt probably exactly the way that Jennifer Lawrence felt when she found out she would be in a movie with Liam Hemsworth and Josh Hutcherson. 
They also both feel VERY confident that we will be winning a Grammy for this record!!!! (They haven't said this yet but I bet they will eventually. I'll keep you posted). 
I am thrilled to be able to use a platform that is as incredible as Kickstarter-- it provides a place for us to connect in such a unique way and offers rewards in exchange for your pledge. THANK YOU!!! for taking the time to read/watch/look into my Kickstarter page--I do not take it lightly that you would spend some of your valuable time on me like this! Bless you!!!
Soooo??? You wanna make a record with me??? I would truly love for you to be a part of this project --you have been the most wonderful part of my career all along. You have made the whole thing worthwhile, and it would be an honor to continue making music with you! I'm here, on my rollerblades, inviting you into the process--whether you can give $1 or $2000 (could be cool, just think about it), it's gonna be so fun to have you.
Your fan,

Hello, it’s me! Jac. Thanks for being here...
I’m beyond excited to tell you that we are f i n a l l y recording my debut album! After a year of criss-crossing the United States on tour, and a decade of crafting, scratching and squeezing songs into being, I’d say it’s time. A mentor of mine, after a lovely string of superlatives, looked me dead-in-the-eyes and said, “I hope you make this record before you’re 40.” ALRIGHT. I’m 24, so we could be doing worse, but to his point--I’ve been dreaming up this record since 2010.
Let’s build an 8-track album featuring world-class musicians and deep 70’s pop influences with state-of-the-art production that matches the music’s lyrical sensitivity and melodic depth. 
 If you're new here and unfamiliar with my sound, I’d encourage you to check out these live, one-take recordings of new songs I’ve put out in the past few months. It’s a little sample of what's to come.
Specs:
Our budget is $25,000. Meeting this goal allows us to partner with a phenomenal producer (Quinn Redmond), record a full studio band, and craft a brilliant sound with mixing and mastering engineers. It also means I can illustrate, distribute, and promote the album as well as create those killer rewards listed to your right!
When you support this record, you’ll help employ artists from nearly every facet of Nashville's creative community: co-writers, illustrators, clothing printers (that's right - we're printing local), photographers, videographers, and everyone who walks in and out of the studio!  All these artists have lost self-employment and/or touring income due to COVID-19. There’s no better time to be creating art. You need it. We need it. Your support goes directly to re-vitalizing Nashville's community of creatives. 
Every pledge $55+ receives a graphic tee printed on a sustainable, repurposed tee by Brokeboys Clothing Co. with an illustration by Timothy Edward Carpenter. Note: Because we’re printing on repurposed tee’s, every shirt will be completely one-of-a-kind in color.
The Lyricisist reward contains the album’s lyric booklet with handwritten insights from Jac into each song along with full-color studio images. This image is an example of an open booklet.
It’s not slipped my mind that COVID-19 has made this campaign a big ask. Music-making and finances inhabit new contexts for us all, but I’ve no doubt that this project and team of creators are going to successfully make a record that’s worth every listener’s time and love. I’ve never felt so optimistic and confident in myself, my purpose, and my team. Much of my enthusiasm derives from you all. You’re constantly inspiring us to continue this strange journey. I want you to know that I accept support in all forms. Already, I’ve felt the warmth of mentors, fellow artists, house show hosts, and venues long before this kickstarter was even a thought. Thank you for your kindness and goodwill. :')
All in all, I’m looking forward to sharing who I am with you in these songs. We’re doing this… it’s really time... Thank you for trusting me with this project.
Love, Jac

campaign.story:
Creating The Record
After touring while pregnant in the summer and early fall of 2018, I felt like I had a collection of songs brewing that I was itching to record, but I also had a limited amount of time before baby was due. It didn't end up coming together before he made his arrival, so I accepted that it was not meant to be. A month into being a new mom, exhausted and dazed, my husband setup a Garageband session and talked me into recording while the baby was sleeping. A few demos (and naps) later, the beginnings of a new album began to take shape. I started to get a vision of what songs felt right and what kind of vibe I wanted this album to have. 
Recording demos in the basement
Picking a team to help me record this album was something I that I wanted to consider carefully. I chose Juan Solorzano and Zachary Dyke to produce and engineer, and I am so grateful I did. Their collaborative energy and patience set such a good pace for the recording process. We tracked for a little over a week at Trace Horse Studio in Berry Hill (Nashville, TN). S/O to Scottie and Preston at Trace Horse who were so helpful and accommodating throughout the project. I also had some awesome musicians and vocalists who contributed so much to the sound of this album: Ross McReynolds, Caleb Hickman, Josh Rogers, Benjamin Kaufman, Katie Herzig, Betsy Phillips, and Lori Chaffer, Robby Hecht
Wanna get a preview of my songs? Here are some acoustic versions!
Juan Solorzano and Zachary Dyke
Making a record after the birth of a child is a wild experience and one that opened me up to more vulnerability in my songwriting and recording. It has stretched me, and in many ways parallels the sacrifice, but immense joy of being a mother.  
To stay in touch with my son on studio days, I would send him little videos.
Promoting The Record
The main reason I am doing this Kickstarter is to give my music a chance to make an impact and grow a larger fanbase. I'd like for more people to hear my music, to make that happen I need the support of a PR / Marketing team. This Kickstarter will also help me to afford the material costs to print CD's, Vinyls, and Merch! It takes so much effort, time, and resources to get off the ground with music as an independent artist these days, but the magic of independent music is that your direct support makes this music more than it ever could be on its own. Whatever support you can give, rest assured it will be used with purpose and a sober heart. Thank you for supporting a Momma and musician like me. 
Kickstarter Budget
I want to be upfront with where this money will be going! This is the breakdown!
Kickstarter fees $1,100
Photo shoot, Album and single covers: $2,500
Vinyl Printing at Memphis Record Pressing: $1,400
Vinyl Inscription: $400
PR and marketing at Sideways: $14,000 - This is my biggest expense, but also the most important for getting my record out to more people. I've never done PR before, but feel like this is the project to pull a team behind!
Printed CDs: $540
 Live performance video: $400
500 word biography: $375
Kickstarter Video: $500
Whatever I have left will go towards making merchandise, like t-shirts, posters, etc. and towards the necessary means to get on the road and do some shows!

campaign.story:
Nemo here,
I started writing this song two years ago while on tour with Crea and some friends. We had only officially started dating the day before we left for a week-long tour, and while we were locked in the car I began wondering if I was qualified for a relationship. Doubts and questions popped into my head, and like any musician worth his salt, I decided to process them through song. I wrote the first verse and chorus of Embrace at Crea's family farm in Oxford, Ohio, sitting on a bale of hay by the horses.
A year later, I realized that this song wasn't meant for just me -- that Crea was apt to having the same doubts and fears that I wrestle with, so I asked her to take a stab at writing some lyrics. In a single day, she had finished the song.
This song is an acceptance of the fact that love is not a fully-formed thing. It's not a train you hop on once you're fully prepared. Loving her is a dance, a give-and-take, a development together. All of our fears and faults are merely parts of who we are and what we want a partner for -- to love us through all of it, to meet us in the middle, to embrace us in the chaos. 
It is there, in the pursuit of love, that fear dissipates, and we begin keeping company with hope. I am so excited to share this song with everyone who wants or needs a reminder that we are not anchored by our fears; we are loved regardless.

What are you supporting?
We realized pretty quickly that this song is a substantial step for us as partners, and that the song deserves the best that we can give it. We would love to:
Hire local strings magician, RJ Bracchiatta, to compose and direct a quartet on the recording
Produce a live music video so you can watch us sing Embrace whenever you want
Get this song in the hands of those who want it but don't know it yet by investing in modest PR

Why would you support us?
We realize that there are many things that you could support this holiday season, and honestly, there's much we want to see supported before us (cough, The Nashville Food Project, cough). But ultimately, the choice is yours, and we want to give you a chance to collaborate with us and bring this love song into the world, if you'd like to. 

Thank you, 
Nemo & Crea

On What Inspired This Album & How We're Approaching It
Over the past few years, Lori and I (Don) have each taken turns sneaking out to our studio to record on a song or two while the other holds down the home front. But thirty or more songs later, we still haven't released any of mine, and only three of Lori's. Her three songs are beautiful, though. So, that's the first thing.
The second thing is that we've played more shows than usual this year, and recently, we discovered we were both thinking the same thing: that it feels especially good singing and playing together right now, and that maybe we should capture this moment.
So, we're setting those thirty-some other recordings aside, and starting from scratch. We'll sit down, choose our favorites from those and other songs, work them out together as a duo, and hit record. It doesn't have to be just two acoustics and vocals, but we do want to focus on those elements. After a quarter century of singing & playing together, it feels like it's time to document the simplicity of that sound.
On Vinyl
We've never released on vinyl, and this seems like an ideal album for it, but vinyl is both expensive to make and to ship (hence the shipping addition we're asking for in the multiple item tiers). Still, it does sound vibey, and setting a needle on a record is a romantic experience, so let's do it.
On Giving This as a Gift For the Holidays
While we won't have these rewards ready in time for the holidays, this would still make a really great Christmas gift. That's why we'll have a downloadable PDF card you can print and give to your loved one to inform them of the super cool gift you bought them. They're gonna love you for this.
On Why We're Kickstarting
Firstly, we love how kickstarter connects us with people early on in the making of an album, and we love the feeling that these songs are part of a communal endeavor.
Secondly, there's the economics. As musicians we always live gig-to-gig, project-to-project. Nothing new there, but in the past decade, the record-making part of our industry has all but disappeared. Streaming just doesn't pay well. In fact, I ran our total Spotify payment history, and for 1,882,719 streams, we've been paid $7,385. Now, I'm not ragging on Spotify. I have it. I love it. I'm just saying Kickstarter is a godsend for independent artists like us, and fans like you. When you pay for these rewards, you're buying an album–yes–but you're also making this album possible. Without you, we literally couldn't do this. We LOVE doing this, and we can't wait to share these songs with you, so a thousand thank you's for partnering with us in this creative endeavor.

campaign.story:
Hey, friend! Can we agree that this world could always use more hope? I'd like to offer my voice as a conduit of hope and healing. By sharing my music in a more accessible way, I believe I can do just that! The songs that come to me most often have hope woven throughout them, whether they are a snapshot of love or loss, joy or grief.  
Up to this point in my musical career, only one of my original songs has been professionally produced and released on music streaming platforms, but there are so many more! That first song was mostly recorded at home - while my kids were sleeping. That process, though life-giving overall, was tedious and stressful. My goal is to record 4 or 5 songs in a real studio with a professional producer. As a stay at home mom, this goal will require more funding and coordinated effort to succeed than simply waiting for naptime, bedtime, or a quiet break in traffic outside.
Who/what/where/how?! I will be working with Casey Williams at Deer/Fox Studio in Durham, NC to track my songs. Recording will take place DURING this campaign. We  begin working on the project this first week! From start to finish, this EP will require $3500 to reach completion.

The risk is *doubled* in that I'm starting the recording process BEFORE I receive these funds. Recording in studio requires immediate payment upfront. If we don't reach the goal together, I'll end up footing the bill on my own and my kids will have a much leaner Christmas. Nobody wants that. Please help us reach the goal! 
Maybe you can't give a lot right now, but maybe you have friends that CAN. Don't underestimate the power of suggestion that YOU HAVE by sharing this project with others!

Hello! Just popping in to say I'm heading back to the studio this evening to redo the vocals for one song. We've gotten to the place of 90% done (or more!) with the EP, but this last bit is filled with excruciating attention to detail. I asked for critical feedback from a handful of you on a couple song drafts, which led me to decide to try again (just on one tho!). I don't want to beat this project up with perfectionism, but on the other hand, I also don't want to rush the process just so that I can say "yay! it's done!". 
Having said all that, please think of me this evening while I *finally* finish vocals. I told Gabe last night that this tail end of the project feels like the last month of pregnancy- so tired, so much doubt and second-guessing, so much wishing it was over already. campaign.story:
I’m turning 30 this month. 
And raising $21k to make new music. 
Here’s some context: 
I’m waving goodbye to my 20s this January, and it has me feeling reflective. I’ve created memories with people I love, got married, moved across the country, and then across the country again. I’m learning how to hold space inside myself for both peace and ambition to coexist. When I'm feeling stuck or unsure of what’s next—I'm finding that if I slow down and listen hard enough, it’s there: the next true thing. Like a note on the trail saying, keep going. There is so much left to feel and find. 
I released my last EP back in 2016 and then booked a house tour—driving my Prius up and down the West Coast playing in living rooms and small venues. That project felt like a rite of passage on so many levels, and I’m feeling that fire inside to create again—building on everything I've discovered since. I spent the summer in New York, and being there was the deep breath I needed as this next project came into focus. 
These new songs are a snapshot of my life over the past few years, and the most personal I've ever written. The deep forest of my mid-twenties and the light through the trees. Love, uncertainty, growth, aching, feeling lost, and then the rare, beautiful moments when the fog lifts. My tracks on the trail. 
I’m recording at The Smoakstack with Paul Moak this March. My studio time is booked— and over the next 30 days, I’ll need your help to raise $21,000 to cover recording, distribution, promotion, and visual components for the record. 
I know it’s a lot of money. But I’m learning that art is a gift to us all because it nourishes, keeps us noticing, awake. Connected. And the truth is I can’t create this alone. I’d be honored to have you along for the ride. If you connect with what I'm doing, I'd also be grateful if you'd consider telling a handful of friends about the project and help me build some momentum online. I've found that thoughtful introductions go a long way and every little bit is meaningful to me.
If you'd like to post about it, here's the link to share: http://bit.ly/rpkickstarter —And I've also consolidated some photos here that you can use for social media. 
I’m endlessly grateful for your support and belief in me thus far—and thank you for considering being a part of what’s next. 
I mean it all. 
xo, 
Rebekah

WE ARE MOVING FORWARD WITH A BIG, NEW VISION...
to modify our approach in order to fulfill our mission with today's media consumer in mind.  We plan to offer more high-quality video content, a new mobile-friendly website, updated branding, new podcast strategy, and more album compilations. We are hoping to become one of the leading voices in Christian independent music.

YOU ARE BACKING UTR'S CREATIVE RELAUNCH...
and the one-time expenses beyond our normal operational expenses. This campaign will specifically provide the following items that will benefit the whole UTR community:

* A new (good) website is not cheap, but worth every penny because it's the organization's welcome mat. We'll be building a robust and beautiful site worthy of a leading media organization. Plus going mobile-friendly is a much needed change for UTR!
* New branding will help modernize the look and feel of the organization. Good branding is vital in attracting a new audience.
* New video content will be a large-scale strategy for sharing well-crafted music moving forward. On-demand high-quality video is in high demand, and UTR can be a leader for faith-inspired independent music.
* New audio content will continue to be produced, but not within the confinements of a syndicated radio program. Our audio content will be more free-form and might even take some new creative directions.
* Our multi-artist compilation albums are the #1 way people are interacting with UTR - even more than our radio show - according to a May 2016 survey. This campaign will help us launch FIVE new NoiseTrade-style compilation albums.

 AND IF THE GOAL IS EXCEEDED...

When it comes to us, it all started in Memphis. We met there in August 2007. We fell in love there. We wrote our first songs together there. We cut our teeth as a band in this blue-collar city before moving to Nashville. Since then, we have played over one-thousand shows in forty-three states and have been privileged to make many friends along the way through the medium of music. So many of our memories are able to exist because of the overwhelming support from so many over the years.
After the birth of our son, Wilder in September 2014 and six years on the road, we decided to pull back the reins. We needed time to reflect and decide what the next step was. Out of this process came several new songs, a renewed passion for our craft and a reminder of why we write and sing. We found ourselves refreshed and ready to turn the page into the next chapter. We just didn’t know where to start.
It’s funny how things have a way of coming full circle. One day, our friends and longtime tour mates in the Memphis band, Star & Micey asked us to come down to Sun Studio to sing with them on a few tunes. After we finished, we all stuck around in the studio. With no real plans, just for fun and almost by accident we began to create something special in that legendary room that would beg to be finished.
With our friend Curry behind the controls, we started into a new song that we had written. The magic of the moment was so real and electric from the first note. The light bulb had come on again. We left Memphis the next day with a clear vision to return and record these new songs completely live with the boys at Sun Studio.
So here we are. We’ve been working on the album slowly but surely over the past year, going back to Memphis for a day or two at a time when it feels right and schedules align to chip away at our newest creation. We’ve gotten ourselves to the halfway point and we want to bring y’all into the fold to be a part of this alongside us. We’ve partnered with Kickstarter to help see this through and to allow you guys to pre-order the new album. By contributing to the project you will be able to receive the new album before it is released, receive some unique incentives that we’ve come up with for you, and you’ll get behind the scenes updates from us along the way.
Every penny of the funds raised will be spent on necessities not only to finish the recording process but to be able to give the new album a proper release and a fair chance to succeed. We wouldn’t have made it this far without all of you and we need your help to keep this thing goin’. We look forward to sharing it with you. Thank you from the bottom of our hearts.

I'll admit it, I'm terrified of asking people for money. I wouldn't ask for anything if there was any other way to create this record, but the truth is I need your help.
In the Spring of 2013, I released my first EP of 5 songs that I had written mostly during high school. I received the most encouraging responses ever from friends, family, and complete strangers, further solidifying that this is an area of my life I want to grow and pursue. 
Since then, so many events have happened that I can hardly wrap my mind around them. The only way I've ever known to cope with anything is to write music that just gets all of my thoughts and emotions out there. I have 10 songs that I am ready to share with everyone that I think are very relevant to all of us.  
The reason I'm entitling this record "Journal Entries" is because that's exactly what these songs are. 
I'm very proud to say that not all of these songs are about boys (a few are though..oops). These are songs about self-worth, growing up, coping with hurt, and life in general. Some of these were songs I wrote in difficult times and the only way to feel better was to sit in my room and play them over and over again. Others were written for dear friends to encourage them and let them know what they are worth. All this to say, I am confident that there are songs on this record that everyone can pull something from. My main goal is to say something that might resonate with someone and make them feel understood. I am only recording what I feel are my best songs from the past 2 years and I feel so lucky that we could possibly release them as a team! 
Thank you for even considering investing in this project!
The fact that you are even reading this means the world to me. If you all come behind me, know that I will put in as many hours as it takes to get the most quality product possible to you as well as all the fun rewards you see on the side!
I am passionate about this project and I hope you will be too. 
Thanks SO much again for all of your support, I'm looking forward to starting this journey together!

campaign.story:
One of the problems with being an indie artist is you have a lot of cool, fun, ideas for future projects but not always the time or money to do them all in the timeframe you'd like.  One GREAT thing about being an indie artist is that you don't have to wait for industry "gatekeepers" to sign off on these ideas to get the ball rolling!
I have the next 4 musical projects mapped out (and have started the writing and pre-production recording process on one of them) and need your help on the first three ideas.  So instead of making three similar but different sounding records every two years, I've decided to trim the fat and make them into three EPs over the course of ONE YEAR.  (Possibly less.  But we'll see.)  Here's the skinny:
EP 1: Futureboy
Yes, the title is a Back To The Future reference.  But also the songs that I've been writing for it all line up with a common theme of time travel. Not necessarily in the literal sense, but in the way we let our minds wander to the pain and pleasure of the past, so often worry and wonder about the coming days, and lastly the struggle to be present in our every day lives.  The production on this EP will be really fun and different from anything I've ever done before...in a GREAT way!

EP 2: Christmas collab Stacy Lantz
This past December, Stacy Lantz and I wrote a couple holiday songs and took them on the road to "beta test" the idea of making a record and doing more holiday themed tours.  Well the shows were a blast, and the songs seemed to go over great, so we decided to make an EP of these songs to release around the time when you're ready for Christmas music. 
EP 3: Strip It Down
Lastly, I've wanted to put out a record that was bare-bones production (acoustic, piano, and voices) for a while.  These are always my favorite types of recordings, the ones where you feel like you're sitting on the floor 2 feet from the players and hearing each line like it was just written.  Full of heart, stories, and honesty.

campaign.story:
One story, unlimited possibilities . . .
“In a world where anything can happen, there can only be OneStory . . . “
The goal: Travis Thrasher (that’s me) will write and publish a 75,000-100,000 word novel with the help of YOU. The goal will be to have the book published by spring, 2015.
YOU: Maybe you’ve always wanted to write but never have the time. Maybe you’re a passionate reader full of ideas. Maybe you’d love to be a part of a project like this that will bring together a wide variety of people. Maybe you're a massive Travis Thrasher fan. Maybe you’re simply a creative soul and this sounds like fun.
ME: I’ve wanted to be a writer since third grade. I worked at a publishing company as Author Relations Manager for thirteen years learning what makes authors tick. I’ve been a fulltime writer for seven years now collaborating with everyone from Blake Shelton’s mother to filmmakers to the guys at Duck Dynasty.
Now I want to collaborate with YOU!
I want one person to select the premise for the novel. Another to pick the genre. Another to pick the setting. And so on.
Sure, those are the big choices. But you can contribute in small but still meaningful ways! Like thinking of a fun phrase to use. Or even a clever sentence.
Who will our hero be?
What cliché must go into our story?
If you think the end result is going to be some sloppily-written novel, THINK AGAIN. This might be the best thing I ever do. Because I have brilliant people like yourself giving me ideas!
This is what I’ve learned: collaborating is FUN.
Sometimes the more ideas you can get, the better the project can be.
Obviously my job will be to get all the ingredients in place and then make something awesome out of it.
WHAT MAKES THIS AN AWESOME IDEA?
Nobody has done this.
Someone in California and Key West and North Dakota can all share in the process of creating a book.
We’ll have a fabulous book at the end of this. Unpredictable. ZANY.
You get to watch as the story literally unfolds in front of you. A story that you're a part of. 
HOW CAN I BELIEVE YOU’LL BE ABLE TO PULL THIS OFF?
I don’t know another author out there who can write a sweet Nicholas Sparks-style love story and then turn around and do a Stephen King-style horror novel. I’ve done both and everything in between.
Making stories out of songs? Done that.
Making stories out of screenplays? Yep.
Making stories out of true-life situations? Yep again.
Ghostwriting? Sure I’ve done that!
Adventure? Thriller? Romance? Drama? Literary? Christmas? Yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, and yes.
This project will allow me to do something wildly creative and FUN. And we will all be in this together!
HOW WILL THIS WORK?
I have no idea whatsoever. No, I actually have some idea.
First we launch the campaign. People pick what they want to contribute. DON'T SEND ME THE IDEA RIGHT AWAY! Keep it until we see what happens after 30 days. I don't want anybody swayed by what the idea will be. 
If we reach our goal, then I will begin to communicate with every person who is contributing. I will start with a premise if picked and go from there. Soon I will begin to create a story outline full of names and places and situations.
I will assemble all the ingredients and then will share with all of you what I'll be writing. If there are contradictory issues (a situation not fitting into the premise, something like that), I will address it with the creator.
I will be communicating with you all along the way, letting you know how the story is taking shape. I’m sure there are going to be some major challenges. But that’s the exciting part!
Consider this to be a diary of sorts on the journey of writing a book, from the very beginning of the ideas to the final line.
The goal will be to finish the story by spring, 2015. To publish a piece that has every bit of input from all of YOU!
WHY $15,000??
My goal is to approach this as if this is a regular trade book that will be edited, copyedited, proofread, typeset and designed by professionals. I work with all of those so I want to make this the best possible book it can be.
This won’t look like a self-published book. This is going to look like something that Jimmy Fallon or Matt Lauer might hold up to the camera right before interviewing me.
Wait, you’re laughing. Don’t laugh. I’m being serious.
BUT WAIT—THERE ARE NO T-SHIRTS?? NO GOODIES??
This is all about the creation and the collaboration. BUT . . .If we reach our goal, then we will start adding fun additional STUFF with the stretch goals. These can be adding more choices to the book along with materials related to OneStory.
OOOHHHH. . . . STRETCH GOALS?! TELL ME MORE.
If this surprises all of us there’s a vast array of resources I can use to create fun things associated with this. Yes, t-shirts. Stickers. Logos. Cool posters. Songs. Videos. If you know me, you know I'm FULL of ideas. 
But look.
At the end of the day, this isn’t about accumulating more STUFF.
It’s about taking a journey.
AND THE JOURNEY IS EVERYTHING.
It’s about seeing what it’s like to create a novel and write and finish it.
You’ll be alongside me every step of the way.
RULES
1. Don’t be vulgar or sacrilegious in any of your choices
2. Do not use anybody’s name or story without their permission
3. All ideas submitted will be the property of OneStory for the author (me) to use them in whatever capacity he deems fit. (If you really have that home run idea, save it for yourself)
4. If two ideas directly contradict themselves (meaning they make no possible sense no matter how hard the author tries), the author will use the idea with the higher value and go back to the other contributor to get another idea.
5. Dream sequences are totally viable. Yes, we’ll probably see lots of dream sequences. And surely a character losing his mind (like every other Travis Thrasher novel).
6. No animals or small children should be injured in the idea building for this book.
7. Any rules broken here will result in the idea not being used. But let’s break the rules for how a novel is created and craft something that’s incredible!

Makoto Fujimura has a vision to reinvigorate culture, to help us see culture as an ecosystem in which we all must live rather than a battlefield on which we fight. There are no winners in a culture war, and the over-commodification of culture poisons our cultural soil and water and fragments our humanity. But recognizing this situation is an opportunity for a new beginning, a genesis moment. As with nature, human culture can recover and thrive when people exercise their creative gifts in stewardship.
Last winter, Mako introduced Culture Care with a little booklet, “On Becoming Generative.” Culture Care is a vision for presenting our culture with a bouquet of flowers—for reconnecting our culture with beauty. It is an invitation to join a constructive conversation with fresh categories, and a call to cultivate the soil of culture so that it can flourish. Culture care is for everyone: artists and cultural catalysts, academics and activists, church and government workers, business and civic leaders. Everyone has a role in restoring beauty to benefit ourselves and coming generations.
The award-winning booklet has already sparked responses from people in academia, the church, and the business and nonprofit worlds. Now the same team (designer/artist Lindsay Kolk, artist and culture shaper Makoto Fujimura, and editor Peter Edman) is ready to move to the next level with a book on Culture Care—and we need your help!
The Culture Care book includes constructive chapters and illustrations to launch conversations on topics including beauty, the care and feeding of the soul, crossing borders and building bridges, overcoming poisoned language, caring for artists, nurturing true competition, and nonviolent resistance to the culture wars.
The goal of this campaign is to raise funds for International Arts Movement (the parent nonprofit of the Fujimura Institute) to self-publish the book. Proceeds from the sale of the book will support and propagate the ongoing Culture Care effort. This is an opportunity for you to support Culture Care by pre-purchasing the book (and saving money!), and to help us to gauge how many copies can be printed. If your response is strong, IAM can reduce direct costs and print more copies.
Dig in now to become one of the early “gardeners.” Share the message of Culture Care with others and save some money for yourself! Weary of the culture wars? Join the resistance and start cultivating gardens that can feed the soul.

In ending this successful campaign toward Culture Care, I want to share with you an excerpt from the book:
In August 1963, prior to giving his “I Have a Dream” speech at the March on Washington, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. found himself exhausted by a series of setbacks, imprisonments, oppressions, and disappointments. He was so physically spent that he spent many hours simply resting while his followers wrote the speech he was to give to the historic gathering. One of his close aides, Clarence Benjamin Jones, said that “the logistical preparations for the March were so burdensome that the speech was not a priority for us,” and that, “on the evening of Tuesday, August 27, [twelve hours before the March] Martin still didn’t know what he was going to say.” After walking a few miles to the Lincoln Memorial, he stood to read the prepared text, but he knew something was not right.

Don & Lori Chaffer of Waterdeep have a fantastical double album underway, but you can help them finish it.
TWELVE HOURS left in the campaign! You are our heroes. Just do us one last favor, and spread the word about this campaign. Many of you have already, of course, but here in the last 12-hours, let's give it a real heave-ho. On three...

STRETCH GOAL UPDATE
$25K- Met. We've resumed work on the record. It's hard to sleep. We're re-writing lyrics, re-harmonizing chord changes, pondering reverbs, drum sounds, strings, horns, choirs...
$28K- Met. Our Original "Secret" Budget is met. We're going to actually have TIME to make this thing really good, AND the money to invite co-conspirators into it: singers, players, and nare-do-wells, oh my.
$35K- Met. Videos, y'all. We're buying a camera. Get ready for what will surely be the first in a long line of Waterdeep oscar-bid videos.
As Yet Unmet Stretch Goals (see below)... You have inspired us. It's like we have tempera paint in our veins. Imagine a cross between, like, a finger-painting pre-schooler, and The Terminator. That's us now, thanks to you. We feel unstoppable, full of magic-whirly-twirly-love-and-sunshine, shooting out of our fingertips...
We're planning for the Waterdeep future. Seriously, though, Lori and I have talked a lot about this influx of money, tools, and renewed (and new) connections being a game changer. For quite a while, Waterdeep has, by necessity, sat on the back burner. What if it doesn't have to anymore?
Thanks beyond expression,
Don & Lori Chaffer (Waterdeep)
WHAT FOLLOWS BELOW IS THE FIRST MAIN PAGE UPDATE:
It Feels Good To Be Waterdeep Like This Again
We asked you for $20,000, and, in less than 48 hours, you said “Sure thing. Here you go.” Our jaws dropped. We tweeted. We facebooked. We graffitti’d highway overpasses with the word “amazing.” We're humbled and grateful.
Also, all this love (and money) has made us feel like recording artists again. After a hard day with the kids or the studio (working on someone else’s album) it's easy to wonder whether it still matters that we write songs from our hearts. Not trying to be a sad sack. Just sayin' that when you all said “Yes, it matters,” it felt really, really good.
Now, let's address some outstanding questions about the campaign in mock interview format. Lori and I will play the role of "Us;" you will play the role of "You."
You: Awesome, Don & Lori. Happy for you. Can we still give you money?
Us: YES!
You: Is the kickstarter still going now that you’ve met your goal?
Us: YES! Until that number on the right gets down to “0 days to go,” the campaign is still going, and you can still give.
You: Do you still need more money?
Us: When we made a budget for finishing the double album, it came to $27,665, but when we imagined missing that goal by $1, and getting nothing as a result, we said, “Yeah… I mean… but… we could still squeak by with $20,000, right?” Thus, a kickstarter goal was born. As of this writing, we’re past our official goal, and almost to our original “secret” goal.
You: What happens with any extra money you make?
Us: See our next section “Stretch Funding Goals.” However–and I hope you’re okay with this–we’re gonna end the mock interview format.
You: Sure. That’s cool. It’s been nice, though, you know, chatting.
Us: Oh, man, for us too. Thank you… (voice cracking) for everything. (“You” and “Us” hug, tears forming in both of “Our” eyes.)
STRETCH FUNDING GOALS
Here are the things we plan to do with our money if we make even more amazing amounts than the amazing amounts you’ve already given us. Mind you, I should probably set aside some cash first to look up more superlatives. As amazing as the word “amazing” is, I bet it’s getting old.
STRETCH GOAL #1 ($25K) RESUME WORK ON ALBUM – GOAL MET!
We’ve already started working again on the double album because of your generosity. We're thrilled.
STRETCH GOAL #2 ($28K) REACH THE SECRET BUDGET NUMBER 
We’ll have hit our original goal, the "secret" one we made, before we got nervous and lowered it. At $28,000, we'll be able to make the process better for both ourselves and others (i.e. pay musicians and designers better, take a bit more time on things, stuff like that). And when we're done, you'll hear a better album than $20,000 would have given us. How cool is that?
STRETCH GOAL #3 (35K) MAKE A VIDEO ON A NEW CAMERA 
We’ll go out and buy a camera, tripod, and, like, maybe a lens cloth, and make another video. It’ll either be a short documentary on the "Making of", or it’ll be a music video. Not sure yet which.
STRETCH GOAL #4 (40K) MAKE ANOTHER VIDEO ON OUR NEW CAMERA
The camera will still be new, and we’ll make the other video… the one we didn’t make for the last stretch fund goal. Like, if we made the music video for GOAL#3, then we’ll make the documentary for GOAL#4. If we made the documentary for…
Lori: Don, they get the idea.
Don: Okay.
STRETCH GOAL #5 (50K) TO INFINITY AND BEYOND
I started to spend a lot of time budgeting out other things we might do if we make more than this, and then Lori–who is, as many of you now know, the voice of reason in our family–suggested we just let people know what some of those other things might be, and cross that bridge when we come to it. She’s right, as usual. So, here are some of the things we discussed:
Don Chaffer – An Unfinished Tale, Vol. 3, Strange – a Spoken Word Album
I would record some more readings of my poems, like I did on the first two Unfinished Tale solo albums; maybe also a small chap book of all the poems from the first three volumes.
Waterdeep Theater
We would produce a theatrical Waterdeep show involving: actors, musicians, lights, costumes, and maybe puppets. It’d be a cross between a regular Waterdeep show, Late Night with David Letterman, and the musical, Wicked (which, technically, I have never seen). Rad. We’d run the show for several weekends in Nashville, and possibly take it to other town(s) as well, for weekend runs in small 100-200 seat theaters.
Son of a Gun Full Musical Recording
My first musical, Son of a Gun (co-written with playwright, Chris Cragin Day, as well as Lori, on additional music) premiered in NYC in November, 2012. A few of you got to see it. Most of you didn’t. Due to Actor’s Equity Union issues, we were unable to video it for you. However, what we can do is record the entire musical in audio form–both the songs AND the dialog.
More Shows and Touring
If we make a bunch of money, we could finally afford a minivan, instead of the Honda Accord we presently use for “touring.” I put “touring” in quotes because our show schedule has been miserably sparse the past few years. 
Get that minivan.
Change the touring schedule, and change the world!
Right now. With us. Together.
WHAT FOLLOWS HERE IS THE ORIGINAL KICKSTARTER TEXT:
On Our History (Briefly, With an Apology For the Word "Farewell")
About twenty years ago, my wife (Lori Chaffer), and I (Don Chaffer) formed a band called Waterdeep. We used to tour a lot. We made a lot of records, and people used to buy them, back when people bought records. We were even on a record label for a while, back when people used to be on record labels. In 2004, we took a break from touring (a.k.a. had a kid). That's when we had our famous "Farewell To Touring Show."  I'd like to take this moment to admit that I am indeed the one responsible for choosing the phrase "Farewell To Touring Show." As it turns out, "Farewell to Touring Show" sounds a lot like "Farewell Show." So–while we've released over ten records since then,–we continue to have people ask, "Didn't you guys break up?" Well, no. We didn't. But I did once use a phrase that made it sound like we did. Sorry about that.
On How We Make a Living
After I sabotaged the public perception of Waterdeep's existence, I moved on to other areas of the music business. For the past ten years I've earned my living by: running a studio, producing other people's albums, writing songs for and with others, making instrumental music for film &TV, and doing musical theater jobs (from composing/writing/arranging down to bits of amateur acting). Lori, meanwhile, has cared for our two kids and home,  run the books for and administrated the business, written songs for and with others, collaborated on the musicals, and sung a heckuva lot of background vocals on people's albums.
On This New Album (And On Two Solos Verses One Double)
Despite all this, we still write songs for ourselves, and they get to banging around inside of us. So, about once a year, we gather these songs together in the studio. Voila. Waterdeep album. This past year, when it came time to record, we each had enough songs to fill an album individually. So, we started two separate solo projects, but realized they were still artistically connected to each other. Voila. Waterdeep Double Album.
On Why We're Inviting Your Participation
We couldn’t finish it. Right now, the songs are just sitting, lonely, on a hard drive. Meanwhile, all around Nashville (a.k.a. “Music City”) studios are closing; labels, downsizing; and publishing companies are letting long-time writers go. Record budgets have shrunk; royalties, diminished; and film & TV doesn't pay what it used to. So, while my schedule has been extremely busy, our financial life's still mostly gig to gig. Furthermore, we never make money on a Waterdeep album until after it's finished. That's where you come in. If you support us through kickstarter, we have enough up front money to get the album done. We can feed ourselves, the songs are no longer lonely on their hard drive, and you get a new album. You can also get a whole bunch of other stuff (see rewards at right).
On Why This Whole Thing is Worth It (And Other Existential Concerns)
We can't shake the feeling that these songs are important. As life goes on, it gets more difficult: parents grow ill, loved ones pass on, marriages crumble, finances get tight, children find their own life problems. Of course, in the midst of all that, there are a thousand mercies and wonders, from daily sunlight, to the ocean of interactions we have with one another. Lori and I have talked often about how these new songs salute complicated realities, and embrace both wonder and sadness. They remind us that this is just human life, and it's pretty great to be alive, even when it hurts.
On Why You're Important To Us, and to This Album
Having not toured as much in recent years, our interaction with all of you has sadly dwindled. We still stay in touch with some of you through social media, and you with us, but we used to have such times together out there on the road, didn't we? I know we're all busy, but this is a chance for us to re-connect, to re-capture some things, and for you to remind your friends that we didn't break up after all ("No," you say, "They called it 'Farewell TO TOURING'... I know. Bad name.... Yeah. They know that"), and for us to bond over a new set of songs at a new shared time of life. We hope you want this as much as we do.
On the Budget, why $20,000?
The budget includes all of the costs of: hiring musicians, finishing the recording and mixing, mastering, package design, manufacturing, promotion, and of course, the money we need to cover the bills while I turn down other work. It's a pretty low number for a double album, by the way.
On Having the Room to Choose
It recently occurred to me that I spend more time and energy making other people's albums than I do our own. Having this money set aside will give us the room to make more deliberate artistic decisions. We will still be insanely efficient with your money. I can run Pro-Tools-Hot-Key circles around most people. Seriously. I don't play.
On "Inflexible" funding And The Importance of the Goal
This is NOT a flexible-funded project. If we don't make the $20,000 goal, we don't get anything at all. That's how kickstarter works. So, when it comes to giving to this project, our livelihood is in your hands. No pressure.
On Stretch-Fund Goals
If we get more than the $20,000, we’re going to use that money for Waterdeep-related work:
-We'll promote this record more. We've made the joke before that we release a record by whispering into our closet that it's out. Sad, but true. Real promotion takes both time and money. So, let's create some of both.
-We'll buy a video camera, so we can make more videos like this one. Dang. That was fun. Music videos, sketch comedy, poetry readings, Pro Tools tutorials, Cooking with Lori. All sorts of crap.
-We’ll write and record more songs. No explanation necessary. I'm guessing you know what songs are. Man, we love songs.
-And then if you surprise us, and the money just keeps coming, I may write a book of Waterdeep poetry. Lori may score a Waterdeep film. We may actually hit the road. There may be some kind of weird hybrid Waterdeep/theater piece I may or may not have already started working on with or without having told Lori about it. Oh, and I'll probably start method acting classes, and keep honing my acting chops… every night… upstairs, in the room over the garage… where I will become the new Daniel Day Lewis... and probably do the definitive bio pic of Millard Filmore, America's underrated 13th president.
Thanks in advance, everyone. We love you. Really. Even those of you we don’t know yet, or whose names we forgot. When we meet you, we’ll apologize for forgetting, and then... A big group hug. Yes. A big group hug to all of you.
Sincerely,
Waterdeep
Don & Lori Chaffer

campaign.story:
It's a simple question - well, actually a series of several very simple questions: would you like some new music from me? Would you like to hear an un-produced, stripped down, solo, electric, live album? Or would you like a fully produced, fancy, beautiful, full length, studio album? Or, would you like both? This is the project that lets you decide the answer to those questions.
Here's the story:
I have been kicking around ideas in my head for over a year now, champing at the bit to record another full length album, as it's been over SIX YEARS since I've released one of those. I've had a lot of fun over the last few years, recording and releasing my music more frequently (with EPs, not full length albums), working with different producers to get different sounds, meeting new people around Nashville, and growing further as a writer and singer. It's been a great few years, during which I recorded and released the four aforementioned EPs, the last three of which (referred to as The Trilogy), I raised support for through generous fans like you on a previous Kickstarter campaign! I've worked with awesome folks, toured around the country in support of those projects, and found new friends, fans and supporters along the way. 
Ever since finishing up The Trilogy project in 2012, I've had a strong desire to record another full length album. I feel like it's time- like the season of EPs is over. And I've been wanting to do something different, too. I'd like to set up a mic in front of me, and a mic in front of my electric guitar, and sing these new songs live, with as little re-do's and overdubbing as possible. I think that sounds like great fun.
But, since it's my first full length album in SIX YEARS, I also have a strong desire to get into a great studio with a great producer and some great musicians and turn out an awesomely polished piece of work.
I have been torn between these two desires for quite some time, trying to determine the best course of action. Then, washing dishes at home one day, I had the thought- Could I do both?! And then I thought, why not try? So here we are. I have a lot of new songs and I want to record them. There might be some overlap, if particular songs lend themselves to both stripped down and produced versions, but for the most part they will be two separate full length albums with different songs- put together as a double album.
The goal of $16,000 is the budget- It includes recording costs for both albums, mixing and mastering fees, album artwork, CD duplication, and reward fulfillment costs. Anything we raise beyond the goal will be put to good use for press campaigns and promotional costs. So, check out all the rewards to the right, see if this is something you're excited about being a part of, and pick the reward package you like the most! The Story
It was June 10, 2010 The most memorable day for Carolina Story.
A morning when we said to one another, let's give up and do something else besides creating music. Later that exact same day we were at the grocery store together and a woman stopped us, asking if we were carolina story and explained how she'd enjoyed watching us play at a local coffee shop.
Not really in the right head space to hear her compliments, we politely said thank you and moved on down the next aisle. But it was then that she steered her shopping cart in reverse and looked back to us and said, "I feel like today Im supposed to tell y"all to NEVER GIVE UP!"
Nearly 500 shows, 36 states, and two countries later, those are still the words that keep us going. We've heard those words numerous times through significant, ordinary people who've come across our music. Whether it was a show filled with people or a show where there were only 2. Its people who keep inspiring us over and over again.
Carolina Story has always been the two of us at the very core, but so many, many more people make up our story and now for the first time we have an opportunity to reach so many more people with this next record and not only that but to include the people we've met along the way in the process of making this next record.

This song in the above video, "If I Were Brave," is one I wrote from my favorite songwriting perch in my kitchen in Nashville a little while back, and it's one I return to mentally sometimes, asking myself, "What would I do right now (whatever the situation) -- if I behaved like I weren't afraid?" And then I try to tell myself, "Then do that!" So that's something like this Kickstarter project. I am trying to record my second full-length studio album while finishing my Master's degree (and keeping my job) -- and I don't have a lot of time to work with! From the time of my Kickstarter launch to its end on March 1, 2012 is less than three weeks! And I'll plan to release the record at the end of March 2012. So, if you resonate with this song and want to hear more songs like it, please consider becoming one of my backers, and let your friends know about it, too!
In return for your support, you will get rewards of various kinds (which you can read about on the right-hand side of this page). I am excited about this Kickstarter model of arts patronage that allows art-lovers (even those of modest income) to support the creation of art -- in this case, music -- in a specific and meaningful way. You will quickly see that your contribution makes a tangible difference: Give money towards music....Wait a few weeks....Then voila! Receive the music that you helped make happen!
The crucial catch with Kickstarter, though, is that I have to raise ALL of the target goal, or I will receive NONE of the funds. Any funds OVER the goal will just make the record that much better! But, your credit card will be charged ONLY if the pledge goal is met. So it is really a no-harm, no-foul situation for you. My studio costs are being partially subsidized through a grant, but there are still many expenses involved in the project: studio overhead, mixing, mastering, duplication, and so on...!

Hi friends! While many of you were busy watching the Oscars last night, not ALL of you were, because yesterday evening this unlikely little Kickstarter campaign quietly but steadily crept up to its funding goal -- and then even surpassed it! WOOHOO! We did it!!
Each person who contributed played a crucial part, and I am so, so grateful. It was a very exciting moment when I realized the goal was met. It almost seemed like today should be a holiday, or that I should get a day off work or something, just to celebrate. But, you'll be pleased to know, I was a responsible citizen and did, in fact, turn up for my office job, Kickstarter glory aside.  : )

As of this writing, there is still one full week until March 1st (the official end of this Kickstarter campaign) -- and only about $300 left to raise of my original minimum goal of $4000. Today alone, even the last few hours, several hundred dollars has been pledged. I am FLOORED by all of this! Seriously. Your generosity. Your willingness to share this with friends. Your kind words, and notes of encouragement to me, and stories of your own being-brave.... Wow. Just, WOW.  
It is hard to describe how un-glamorous, un-cute, and un-shiny the songwriting process can be, even if cool-looking videos and other artwork get made around some of the final results. The words and music sometimes come out of lonely and difficult places -- whether personally experienced, or empathetically imagined, by the songwriter. To see an individual listener respond and meet a song with his or her own perspective imbues the work with more meaning than it would have had without that listener and the story that he or she brings to the listening.
